title: 108_hr898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lumbee Recognition Act". The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to acknowledge the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes, recognized by the State since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. The Congress now finds that the Lumbee Indians should be entitled to full Federal recognition. The Lumbee Tribe should be granted full Federal recognition with all benefits and privileges. The Lumbee Tribe should be granted full Federal recognition with all benefits and privileges, as stated in SEC. 3. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to extend Federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, granting them all benefits and services provided to federally recognized tribes. Non-enrolled Indians in Robeson and adjoining counties can petition for tribal acknowledgement. Members residing in specific counties are deemed to be residing near an Indian tribe. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is granted Federal recognition and eligible for services provided to federally recognized tribes. The Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services will develop a budget for services, based on a tribal roll verified by the Secretary of the Interior. The tribal roll defines the service population and must comply with membership criteria set in the tribe's constitution. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is granted Federal recognition and eligible for services provided to federally recognized tribes. The tribe seeks to convey fee lands to the United States to be held in trust, treated as 'on-reservation' trust acquisitions if located within Robeson County. The State of North Carolina shall exercise jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands owned by the Lumbee Tribe. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to accept transfers of jurisdiction from the State of North Carolina. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina seeks to transfer jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions to the State of North Carolina, with a 2-year delay in effect. This transfer does not affect the Indian Child Welfare Act. Appropriations are authorized to implement this Act.
